My Projects

Welcome to a summary of some of my most exciting projects! Each one represents a unique application of data science, machine learning, and analytics to solve real-world problems. Click on the links to explore the full project details and GitHub repositories.

Health Science Calculator

Health Science Calculator is a Python package designed to provide accurate and efficient health metric calculations. It supports Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE), Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR), and Body Mass Index (BMI) computations, making it useful for health professionals, researchers, and fitness enthusiasts.

This project was developed as part of a collaborative effort using best practices in software engineering, automation, and version control to ensure code quality, maintainability, and scalability.

Project Goals & Contributions

‚úî Developed a modular Python package for health-related calculations using object-oriented programming (OOP) principles. ‚úî Implemented core functions to compute BMI, BMR, TDEE, and perform unit conversions to standardize health data. ‚úî Integrated Pytest for automated testing, ensuring the accuracy of implemented functions and maintaining 100% test coverage. ‚úî Leveraged GitHub Actions for CI/CD, automating testing, deployment, and ensuring seamless version control. ‚úî Published the package to PyPI, making it accessible for installation and use via pip install healthsciencecalculator. ‚úî Collaborated with a team, applying version control workflows (branching, merging, pull requests) to streamline development. ‚úî Designed an API reference and technical documentation using Sphinx and Read the Docs, ensuring clarity for users.

Technical Implementation 1Ô∏è‚É£ Core Functionality The package provides key health-related calculations:

üìå get_tdee() ‚Äì Calculates Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) based on BMR and activity level. üìå get_bmi() ‚Äì Computes Body Mass Index (BMI) and classifies users into categories (underweight, normal, overweight, obese). üìå get_bmr() ‚Äì Uses the Harris-Benedict equation to compute Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) based on weight, height, age, and sex. üìå unit_convert() ‚Äì Converts between metric and imperial units for weight, height, temperature, and volume.

üí° Each function is rigorously tested and optimized to provide high-accuracy calculations.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Continuous Integration & Deployment (CI/CD) To ensure code stability and reliability, I implemented GitHub Actions for CI/CD, enabling:

‚úî Automated testing via Pytest after every code commit or pull request. ‚úî Linting and style checks using Pylint to maintain code consistency. ‚úî Test coverage reporting using pytest-cov and Codecov for tracking improvements. ‚úî Automated package deployment to PyPI using GitHub Actions, ensuring seamless updates.

üîπ CI/CD Workflow Overview:

Push or Pull Request: Triggers automated tests on GitHub Actions. Run Pytest: Tests all functions for expected outputs, error handling, and edge cases. Deploy to PyPI: If all tests pass, the package is automatically updated on PyPI. üí° Impact: CI/CD ensures code quality, early bug detection, and smooth integration into production.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Automated Testing with Pytest Testing is crucial in health applications, so I implemented comprehensive unit tests using Pytest:

‚úî Validated all health metric calculations against known industry standards. ‚úî Implemented edge-case handling (e.g., division by zero, incorrect input types). ‚úî Ran parameterized tests to ensure correctness across various inputs. ‚úî Tracked test coverage using pytest-cov, achieving 100% test coverage.

üí° Testing Commands:

bash Copy Edit # Run all tests pytest

Run tests with coverage report

pytest ‚Äìcov=healthsciencecalculator 4Ô∏è‚É£ Collaboration & Version Control Working on this project in a team required effective version control:

‚úî Used GitHub for repository management, implementing branching strategies and pull requests. ‚úî Code reviews were conducted for all new features, ensuring high-quality contributions. ‚úî Maintained a changelog to document package updates and feature improvements.

Installation & Usage üìå Install the package via pip:

bash Copy Edit pip install healthsciencecalculator üìå Example Usage:

python Copy Edit from healthsciencecalculator import get_bmi, get_tdee

Calculate BMI

bmi_result = get_bmi(weight=70, height=1.75) print(f‚ÄùBMI: {bmi_result.bmi:.2f}, Category: {bmi_result.category}‚Äú)

Calculate TDEE

tdee = get_tdee(bmr=1500, activity_level=‚Äúmoderately active‚Äù) print(f‚ÄùTDEE: {tdee:.2f} kcal/day‚Äù) Key Takeaways & Impact üöÄ Developing a robust Python package strengthened my skills in: ‚úî Software Development ‚Äì Object-oriented programming, modular design, API development. ‚úî Machine Learning & Analytics ‚Äì Data validation, unit conversions, structured data processing. ‚úî Automation & CI/CD ‚Äì GitHub Actions, Pytest, automated package deployment. ‚úî Team Collaboration ‚Äì Git workflows, issue tracking, and effective code documentation. ‚úî Technical Communication ‚Äì Writing clear documentation and API references for user accessibility.

This project enhanced my ability to develop scalable, well-tested software solutions, a skill directly applicable to data engineering, AI, and healthcare analytics roles.

Bank Marketing predictions

Overview The Bank Marketing Prediction Project applies machine learning techniques to enhance bank marketing strategies by predicting whether a customer will subscribe to a term deposit based on demographic and campaign-related data.

The goal was to develop a predictive model that helps banks optimize resource allocation, minimize marketing costs, and improve customer conversion rates. This project incorporated end-to-end data science workflows, data preprocessing, and model evaluation to identify the most effective approach for targeted marketing.

üí° Key Contributions & Impact ‚úî Developed predictive models to classify customer responses to bank marketing campaigns. ‚úî Built a fully reproducible machine learning pipeline using Python and Jupyter Notebooks. ‚úî Implemented Docker for containerized deployment, ensuring portability across environments. ‚úî Used GitHub Actions for CI/CD, automating testing and workflow execution. ‚úî Applied statistical analysis and feature engineering to optimize model performance. ‚úî Conducted error analysis and class imbalance handling to enhance predictions. ‚úî Created a structured reporting system, generating a detailed analysis of the models‚Äô effectiveness.

Project Objectives üîπ Predict Customer Subscription Behavior: Determine whether a customer will subscribe to a term deposit based on demographic and campaign-related data. üîπ Optimize Marketing Strategies: Identify patterns in customer responses to improve targeting and reduce costs. üîπ Automate Data Processing & Model Training: Develop a scalable pipeline using Click, Docker, and Makefiles. üîπ Enhance Model Interpretability: Implement feature importance analysis to guide data-driven decision-making.

Technical Implementation 1Ô∏è‚É£ Data Preprocessing & Feature Engineering Processing raw customer data involved several key steps: ‚úî Handled missing values and inconsistencies using pandas and NumPy. ‚úî Applied feature scaling and normalization for numerical attributes. ‚úî Used one-hot encoding to convert categorical variables into a machine-readable format. ‚úî Class balancing techniques (oversampling, undersampling) to address the imbalance between subscribers and non-subscribers.

Example Code for Data Cleaning & Feature Engineering:

python Copy Edit from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler, OneHotEncoder import pandas as pd

Load dataset

df = pd.read_csv(‚Äúdata/bank-additional-full.csv‚Äù)

Feature scaling

scaler = StandardScaler() df[[‚Äúage‚Äù, ‚Äúcampaign‚Äù, ‚Äúprevious‚Äù]] = scaler.fit_transform(df[[‚Äúage‚Äù, ‚Äúcampaign‚Äù, ‚Äúprevious‚Äù]])

One-hot encoding categorical features

encoder = OneHotEncoder() encoded_features = encoder.fit_transform(df[[‚Äújob‚Äù, ‚Äúmarital‚Äù, ‚Äúeducation‚Äù]]).toarray() 2Ô∏è‚É£ Machine Learning Models & Performance Evaluation Implemented two machine learning models:

üìå Logistic Regression

Focused on interpretability and explainability. Prioritized minimizing false positives, achieving high precision (0.70). Used L1 regularization to prevent overfitting. üìå Decision Tree Classifier

More flexible in handling non-linear relationships. Achieved higher recall (0.23) but increased false positives. Required pruning and hyperparameter tuning for optimal performance. ‚úî Performance Metrics Used:

Accuracy: Measures overall correctness. Precision: Reduces false positives (important for targeted marketing). Recall: Identifies more actual subscribers. F1 Score: Balances precision and recall. Model Performance Results:

Model Accuracy Precision Recall F1 Score Logistic Regression 88.5% 0.70 0.20 0.31 Decision Tree 89.7% 0.64 0.23 0.34 üí° Findings:

Logistic Regression was best for reducing false positives. Decision Tree performed better in identifying actual subscribers. Further model tuning needed to balance precision and recall. 3Ô∏è‚É£ CI/CD & Automation with Docker & GitHub Actions To ensure reproducibility and scalability, I implemented CI/CD pipelines using Docker & GitHub Actions.

‚úî Dockerized the project for easy deployment. ‚úî Automated testing using Pytest to validate model outputs. ‚úî GitHub Actions triggered CI/CD workflows, ensuring seamless execution.

Example of Dockerized Workflow:

yaml Copy Edit name: CI/CD Pipeline

on: push: branches: - main

jobs: build: runs-on: ubuntu-latest steps: - name: Checkout code uses: actions/checkout@v2 - name: Set up Python uses: actions/setup-python@v2 with: python-version: ‚Äú3.10‚Äù - name: Install dependencies run: pip install -r requirements.txt - name: Run tests run: pytest ‚Äìcov=src üöÄ Impact: CI/CD automation reduced manual intervention, ensuring code integrity and rapid deployment.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Running the Analysis üí° Option 1: Run Using Docker 1Ô∏è‚É£ Install Docker. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Clone the repository.

bash Copy Edit git clone https://github.com/mindy001/BankMarketingPreditions-.git cd BankMarketingPreditions- 3Ô∏è‚É£ Start the container.

bash Copy Edit docker-compose up 4Ô∏è‚É£ Access JupyterLab for interactive analysis.

üí° Option 2: Run Using Makefile 1Ô∏è‚É£ Clone repository and activate environment.

bash Copy Edit git clone https://github.com/mindy001/BankMarketingPreditions-.git cd BankMarketingPreditions- conda env create -f env/environment.yml
conda activate bankenv 2Ô∏è‚É£ Generate analysis report.

bash Copy Edit make all 3Ô∏è‚É£ Open the generated PDF report.

Key Takeaways & Impact üöÄ Through this project, I gained experience in: ‚úî Building scalable ML models ‚Äì Data preprocessing, feature engineering, model selection. ‚úî Data Engineering & Pipelines ‚Äì Automated workflows using Makefile and Docker. ‚úî Machine Learning for Marketing ‚Äì Class imbalance handling, precision-recall tradeoffs. ‚úî CI/CD & Automation ‚Äì GitHub Actions for testing, deployment, and reproducibility. ‚úî Version Control & Collaboration ‚Äì GitHub repository management, pull requests, team contributions.

üîπ Future Enhancements: ‚úÖ Hyperparameter tuning using GridSearchCV for improved accuracy. ‚úÖ Feature selection analysis to reduce redundant variables. ‚úÖ Deploying an API to allow real-time model inference for banks.

Final Thoughts This project strengthened my ability to develop end-to-end machine learning solutions for real-world business challenges. By combining ML modeling, automation, and CI/CD, I created a fully scalable, deployable, and interpretable system.
